Author: jl777c#5810
Content: why cant it be >= solvetime more than past block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if only the hash is made a bit smaller based on tipdiff, it doesnt allow grinding

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as solvetime is not affected

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Hash affects ST which affects VDFout

Author: zawy#5864
Content: ```hash = RandValue / (UTXO qty)```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe the next solvetime

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Yes, that's the grinding attack...increases chances for next block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ```hash = RandValue /( (UTXO qty)*f(tipdiff))```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how can changing tipdiff allow grinding, the hash just gets smaller and smaller. it either wins or doesnt

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it wins, getting smaller wont make it win anymore. and you would submit the first timestamp that wins

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: within FTL

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: Randvalue = function(UTXO, pubkey, previous VDFout)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: entropy source is not affected by the timestamp directly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: VDFout is unchanged

Author: zawy#5864
Content: It seems if he wins by 10 seconds, then he can choose 10 different solvetimes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but the timestamp goes into the block and doesnt change the txid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: using the utxo txid allows grinding

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Changes VDFout

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, i am saying that the calculated solvetime is not changed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just the hash calculation of whether it is lower than bnTarget

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nothing else changes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: indirectly if the DAA is using timestamps, maybe you can affect things, but make the DAA use the solvetime that is calculated

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that avoids the grinding via indirect timestamp changing to change the next solvetime

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but there is risk to delaying the timestamp

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as you need to wait longer due to small FTL and can easily lose the block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this does also spread out the timing of submissions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it also allows nodes that cant calculate VDF within solvetime to still have a chance

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe its not a big deal

Author: zawy#5864
Content: if he gets an improbaby fast solve with tipdiff then he can run 10 different VDFs for 10 different tipdiffs going into future by 1 second each, risking no one else with a solve in next 10 seconds.  He gets 10x more opportunity in next block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but i am saying that there is only a SINGLE valid VDF solvetime

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only a single valid VDF that is not based on tipdiff

Author: zawy#5864
Content: OK, then what is the tipdiff-affected hash being used for if not to reduce the solvetime?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: changes an otherwise losing hash to a winning one

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this also allows to adapt to large changes in amount staking

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at least large drops

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the VDF Solvetime is not changed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only whether a hash wins or not is changed by tipdiff

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess this will affect the next solvetime if you use timestamps to calculate that, but i am saying ignore the timestamp, only use the "VDF Solvetime" for the DAA

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make the tipdiff not affect the next Solvetime, nor the current VDF

Author: zawy#5864
Content: ```solvetime = 2*RandValue * T / avg(N prev STs) / avg(N prev Targets)  / QTY   /   f(tipdiff) ```  What is the f() ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, dont change the solvetime

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just the hash evaluation

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: f() is a "soft" function, maybe a very weak exp()

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Make the hash harder than ST requires?  Validator is checking both VDF and tipdiff?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make the hash solve gradually harder and harder bnTarget, so over time the hash used becomes smaller and smaller

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes all nodes would need to verify the VDF has the right solvetime and that the modified hash did indeed solve the bnTarget

Author: zawy#5864
Content: There would be a DA for the VDF and a DA for the tipdiff hash?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, just DA for VDF

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well maybe that wont work quite right

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess torn between preventing grinding and precise DA

Author: zawy#5864
Content: I thought my idea here to let block-winner set a conversion between VDF and realtime is probably ideal...we sort of need to know that value directly and it prevents the grinding.

Author: zawy#5864
Content: To get the all-important constant value without fiat, stakers need to set difficulty for the POW to mine coins in self-hashing txns.  Being able to surive 51% without BTC like my scheme is supposed to do is good, but the real power is if it can be made stable value without fiat.....a big experiment to see if stakers will act to get constant value as I hope.    Speculation greatly reduced, merchants not needing to worry about price fluctuations.

Content: i solved stable coins using a different method

Content: https://medium.com/@jameslee777/decentralized-trustless-oracles-dto-by-piggybacking-on-timestamp-consensus-rules-2adce34d67b6

Author: zawy#5864
Content: a  peg.....I'm talking about not having a peg to anything other than constant real-world cost to mine... not in dollars but in whatever buyers and sellers think constant value means, assuming stakers act in the best interest of stable value.    If moore's law were constant or predictable, I would not need the stakers to act as an oracle of current mining costs.

It just seems way cool that anyone could turn on a machine, any machine , and have a  little coin they can trade. in a ittle while......except there needs to be a min limit the due to too many txns..... that would be automatic if there is a  fee per byte in txns that exponentially increases as blocks get near a limit.

Content: The difficulty for POW in the header would be in units of  "coin  per hash" instead of  1/hashes required.

Author: zawy#5864
Content: The miner needs to know about what block he'll be finished in and he sets a target and then finds the nonce.  The actual hash isn't needed as there's no chain for coin distribution.
